div.l: I is thyn owne Clerke / so haue I heele
Now dere lemman / ꝙquod she go farwele
But or thou go / oo thyng I wol the telle
Whanne that thou wendyst / homwarde bi the wey
Ryht at thentre / of the dore bi hynde
Thou shalt a cake / of half a busshel fynde
That was y maked / of thyn owne mele
Whiche that I halpe my fadir / for to stele
And good lemman / god saue the and kepe
And wyth that worde / almost she gan to wepe
Aleyn̄ vpryst and thouht / or that it dawe
I wol go crepyn̄ in bi my felawe
And fond the cradyl / wyth his hand a noon
Bi god thouht he al rong / y haue mys gon̄
Myn hedde is doty of my swynk to nyht
That maketh me / that y go not aryht
I wot wol weel bi the cradyll / y haue mys ga
Here lyth the myller / and his wyf Alswa
And forth he goth / a twenty vevyl way
Vn to the bed / ther the myller lay
He wend haue cropyn̄ / bi his felawe Iohn
And bi the myller͗e / he crept in a non̄
And cauht him bi the necke / and gan him shake
He seid Iohn̄ / thou swynes hed awake
For cokkys soule / and here anoble game
For bi that lorde / that called is seynt Iame
As y haue thries / in this short nyht
Swyved the myllers douhtter / bolt vpryht
